title: Bots Nekola
text:
Francis Joseph "Bots" Nekola (December 10, 1906 – March 11, 1987) was an <a href="Americans">American</a> <a href="professional%20baseball">professional baseball</a> <a href="baseball%20player">player</a> and <a href="scout%20%28sport%29">scout</a>. The native of <a href="New%20York%2C%20New%20York">New York City</a> was a <a href="left-handed">left-handed</a> <a href="pitcher">pitcher</a> who appeared in 11 <a href="games%20pitched">games</a> in <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> for the <a href="New%20York%20Yankees">New York Yankees</a> () and <a href="Detroit%20Tigers">Detroit Tigers</a> (). He stood tall and weighed .
Nekola attended <a href="Evander%20Childs%20High%20School">Evander Childs High School</a> and the <a href="College%20of%20the%20Holy%20Cross">College of the Holy Cross</a>. He went from the Holy Cross campus to the Majors, appearing with the Yankees in nine games during their 1929 season, all in <a href="relief%20pitcher">relief</a>. In his big league debut July 19, he pitched 2⅔ <a href="run%20%28baseball%29">scoreless</a>, <a href="hit%20%28baseball%29">one-hit</a> <a href="innings%20pitched">innings</a> against the <a href="Cleveland%20Indians">Cleveland Indians</a>. Nekola made his first <a href="minor%20league%20baseball">minor league</a> appearance the following season, and his career would continue in the minors through 1938, interrupted only by a two-game trial with the 1933 Tigers.
Over eleven major league games, Nekola had a 0–0 <a href="win%E2%80%93loss%20record%20%28pitching%29">record</a> with a 5.85 <a href="earned%20run%20average">earned run average</a>. In 20 total innings pitched, he surrendered 25 hits and 16 <a href="bases%20on%20balls">bases on balls</a>. He <a href="strikeout">struck out</a> two.
Following his playing career, he was the <a href="Boston%20Red%20Sox">Boston Red Sox</a>' longtime <a href="scout%20%28sports%29">amateur scout</a> in the <a href="New%20York%20%28state%29">New York</a> and <a href="New%20Jersey">New Jersey</a> regions. In that capacity, in 1959, Nekola scouted and signed future <a href="Baseball%20Hall%20of%20Fame">Baseball Hall of Fame</a> <a href="outfielder">outfielder</a> <a href="Carl%20Yastrzemski">Carl Yastrzemski</a>. He also would sign future <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball%20All-Star%20Game">All-Star</a> <a href="shortstop">shortstop</a> <a href="Rico%20Petrocelli">Rico Petrocelli</a> as well as <a href="Chuck%20Schilling">Chuck Schilling</a>, a promising <a href="second%20baseman">second baseman</a> whose career was derailed by injury.
He died in <a href="Rockville%20Centre%2C%20New%20York">Rockville Centre, New York</a>.
